article_title: Daughters’ hospitals aren’t alone in facing financial trouble
article_text:
Daughters’ hospitals aren’t alone in facing financial trouble

T he $843 million deal to sell the financially strapped Daughters of Charity Health System hospitals to the for-profit Prime Healthcare Services was always going to come with difficult trade-offs. Prime’s decision to back out of the deal last week, citing state Attorney General Kamala Harris’ “onerous and unprecedented” conditions for the sale, doesn’t change any of the underlying difficulties facing all hospital systems in the Bay Area.

article_metadata.sailthru.author: San Francisco Chronicle
article_metadata.description: The $843 million deal to sell the financially strapped Daughters of Charity Health System hospitals to the for-profit Prime Healthcare Services was always going to come with difficult trade-offs.  Prime’s decision to back out of the deal last week, citing state Attorney General Kamala Harris’ “onerous and unprecedented” conditions for the sale, doesn’t change any of the underlying difficulties facing all hospital systems in the Bay Area.  The Daughters’ hospitals are losing more than $150 million a year because of increasing labor costs and the low medical reimbursement rates it gets for its heavily low-income and indigent patient population.  Desperate to avoid bankruptcy, it made a deal with Prime, a company that specializes in turning around financially distressed hospitals via aggressive cost cutting.  [...] it’s anyone’s guess what will happen to the Daughters hospitals — and what will happen to the indigent patients who depended on those hospitals for medical care.  [...] a perfect demographic storm — America’s aging population, plus the addition of many lower-income patients into the health care system due to the Affordable Care Act — means that things are likely to get worse for hospitals before they get better.  For conditions such as heart disease, asthma and diabetes, patients increasingly take on some management themselves.  Improvements in outpatient services, advances in prescription medicines, and lifestyle changes are all playing a part — and there’s still plenty of room to grow.
